text: All nations compassed me about: but in the name of the LORD will I destroy them.
text_kjv: All nations compassed me about: but in the name of the LORD will I destroy them.
text_niv: All the nations surrounded me,but in the name of the Lord I cut them off.
text_esv: All nations surrounded me; in the name of the LORD I cut them off!
text_nlt: Though hostile nations surrounded me,I destroyed them all with the authority of the LORD.
text_msg: Hemmed in by barbarians,in God's name I rubbed their faces in the dirt;
text_nasb: All nations surrounded me; In the name of the LORD I will surely cut them off.
context: Psalm 118 is a hymn of thanksgiving, likely used in liturgical processions during Jewish festivals, possibly Sukkot (the Feast of Tabernacles). It recounts a time of national distress and deliverance, moving from individual suffering to collective celebration. The phrase "All nations compassed me about" likely refers to historical periods of Israel's vulnerability, such as the Babylonian exile, the constant threats from neighboring kingdoms like the Philistines, Ammonites, and Moabites, or even internal strife and rebellions. These nations not only threatened physical existence but also religious identity, attempting to assimilate Israel into their pagan cultures and belief systems. The use of 'compassed me about' evokes a sense of being surrounded, overwhelmed, and cut off. The psalmist's declaration is not a boast of personal power but a profound statement of faith in Yahweh. Understanding the historical context involves recognizing Israel's recurring experience of being a small, geographically vulnerable nation surrounded by larger, more powerful empires and tribes. The psalm likely emerged from a communal experience of overcoming adversity through divine intervention, reinforcing the covenant between God and His people. Such expressions were crucial for maintaining morale and national identity in the face of persistent external pressures. The phrase 'in the name of the LORD' would have been understood as invoking the full authority and power of God himself, indicating reliance on divine strength rather than military might.
meaning: Theologically, Psalm 118:10 encapsulates several core principles of the Old Testament. First, it demonstrates Israel's consistent reliance on God for protection and deliverance. The psalmist isn't claiming personal agency in destroying their enemies but rather attributing that victory to the power of Yahweh. This highlights the theocentric nature of the psalm, where God is the active agent of salvation. The phrase "in the name of the LORD" is not simply a formulaic invocation but a declaration of God's character, promises, and covenant relationship with Israel. It speaks to the profound belief that God is both willing and able to intervene on behalf of His people. The idea of 'destroying' these nations does not necessarily imply total annihilation but rather overcoming their threatening power. It might refer to political defeat, the thwarting of their plans, or the disruption of their ability to oppress Israel. Theologically, this verse also underscores the concept of God as a warrior king who defends His people against injustice and oppression. It resonates with other passages in the Old Testament where God fights on behalf of Israel, delivering them from their enemies. The verse showcases the contrast between the vulnerability of Israel and the overwhelming power of God. It is a reminder that even when facing insurmountable odds, faith in God can provide strength and victory. Further, it prefigures the New Testament theme of spiritual warfare, where believers are called to resist spiritual enemies through the power of God.
application: In modern application, Psalm 118:10 provides comfort and encouragement to believers facing various challenges. The 'nations' that compass us about can represent different forms of adversity: personal struggles, financial difficulties, health problems, relationship conflicts, systemic injustices, or even spiritual attacks. We can translate the sentiment of the verse by recognizing that, like the psalmist, we are often surrounded by circumstances that seem overwhelming. The key is to emulate the psalmist's response: reliance on God. 'In the name of the LORD' signifies not just reciting a prayer but actively trusting in God's character, promises, and power. Practically, this means seeking God through prayer, studying His Word, and aligning our lives with His will. It also means remembering that we don't fight alone; God is with us and for us. We are called to resist the forces arrayed against us, not through our own strength, but through the power of the Holy Spirit. Just as the psalmist attributed victory to God, we should acknowledge God's hand in our lives, recognizing that He is the source of our strength and deliverance. This verse also challenges us to stand against injustice and oppression in our communities. We are called to be agents of change, working to create a more just and equitable world, but always relying on God's guidance and strength. The destruction mentioned in the verse can be understood as overcoming the negative impact of these challenges on our lives and the lives of others. It is about breaking the power of oppression and creating opportunities for healing, restoration, and flourishing. This requires actively engaging in prayer and working towards solutions while maintaining unwavering faith in God's ability to intervene. We must avoid being paralyzed by fear or discouragement and instead embrace the hope and confidence that comes from knowing that God is with us.
prayer: Heavenly Father, I come before you acknowledging that I often feel surrounded by challenges and difficulties that seem insurmountable. I confess that I sometimes rely on my own strength and understanding instead of trusting in your power. Forgive me for my lack of faith. Help me to remember the words of Psalm 118:10, that in your name, I can overcome any obstacle. Strengthen my faith so that I may always turn to you in times of trouble. Grant me the wisdom and discernment to know your will and the courage to follow it. I ask for your protection and guidance as I navigate the challenges of this day. Thank you for your unwavering love and faithfulness. I pray in the name of Jesus Christ, my Lord and Savior. Amen.

faqs.answer: The word "destroy" in this verse doesn't necessarily imply complete annihilation. It more likely refers to overcoming their power, thwarting their plans, or neutralizing their ability to oppress Israel, thereby securing peace and safety for God's people.
